respStmt.name: Transcription: Peter Robinson, Barbara Bordalejo and members of the Canterbury Tales Project at Oxford and Sheffield (1992-1998), De Montfort University, Leicester (1998-2005), Birmingham (2005-2010), Saskatoon (2010-2013), Virginia Tech, New York University, University of Murcia, Adam Mickiewicz University (Poznan) and Brigham Young University.

publicationStmt.publisher: Textual Communities and the Canterbury Tales Project, University of Saskatchewan

licence.p: All republication of all or any part of this transcript must credit its creators and all who have contributed to it, as listed in the sourceDesc element, and make available free-to-all any work derived from this resource under the same license.
Commercial republication is permitted, in accordance with these terms.

respStmt.name: Transcription: Peter Robinson, Barbara Bordalejo and members of the Canterbury Tales Project at Oxford and Sheffield (1992-1998), De Montfort University, Leicester (1998-2005), Birmingham (2005-2010), Saskatoon (2010-2014), Virginia Tech, New York University, University of Murcia, Adam Mickiewicz University (Poznan) and Brigham Young University.

Oxford transcription team, 1992-1998: Peter Robinson, Elizabeth Solopova, Lorna Stevenson, with contributions from James McCabe, Hubert Stadler, Cathy Swires, Paul and Maureen Watry, Laura Wright, Diana Wyatt and Simon Horobin
Sheffield transcription team, 1992-1998, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson and Simon Horobin
De Montfort transcription team, 1998-2005: Peter Robinson, Barbara Bordalejo, Orietta Da Rold, Gavin Cole, Pip Willcox, Jennifer Marshall, Takako Kato, Jacob Thaisen, Nicole Green
University of Saskatchewan team, 2010-2013: Peter Robinson and Barbara Bordalejo
Virgina Tech team, led by Daniel W. Mosser
New York University team, led by David Hoover and Martha Rust, 2003-2006.

Brigham Young University transcription team, 1995-2006, led by Paul Thomas: Sara Black, Jessica Cox, Barbara Christiansen, Kerry Clift Spencer*, Heidi Elldredge, Leona Fisher Sankhla, Kela Flint*, Melissa Gallup, Shannon Harris, Rebecca Johnson, Mary Jorgensen, Darin Merrill*, Wesley Pack*, Jared Perkins, Jon Penny, Randall Rogers, Ryan Rowberry*, Sara Slack, Carie Soderquist Jackson*, Kat Southerland, Matt Tenney, Briton Wright, John Young. Asterisks after names denote those who supervised other transcribers.

Adam Mickiewicz University, Poznan, transcription team, 2007-2010: (names to be supplied), with support from Adam Mickiewicz University and the The Polish Ministry for Science and Higher Education, grant N104 045 32/4256.
Nila Vazquez Gonzalez, University of Murcia.
Institute of Book Studies and Textual Research of the University of Münster, Germany, c. 2000-2004,led by Gabriele Müller Oberhauser; transcribed by Ulrike Grassnick.

University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.
Original and corrections: Oxford transcription team; corrections: Sheffield team, De Montfort team; conversion for Textual Communities: Saskatchewan team.

div.l: I have a wyfe parde as wel as thow
Yit nold I nat for the Oxen in my plowe
To take oppon me more than I nowe
As demyn of my self that I were one
I wol be leve ther for that I am none
An husbond shuld nat be inquisytyfe
Of Goddis pryvitees ne of his wyfe
So he may fynd Goddis fusou ther
Of þe remnaunt nedith he nat to enquere
What shuld I more sey but this myller
He nold his word for no man for bere
But told his Chorlissh tale in this manere
Me ouyr thinkith that I shal reherce it here
And therfor euery gentil white I prey
Demeth nat for goddis love that I sey
Not for ewil entent but þat I must reherce
Al her talis al be they bettir or werce
Or ellis to falsen som of my matere
And therfor who so listynyth nat to here
Torn owir the lefe and chese a nothir tale
For he shal fynd I now both grete and smale
Of storial thing that towchith gentilnes
And eke moralite and also holynes
Blamyth nat me yf that yee chese amys
The Miller is a Chorll yee knowe wel this
So was the Reve and also othir mo
For of harlotry they told both to
Awisith yewe and put me out of blame
And eke men shul nat take ernest of game
Here endithe the Myller his Prolog
And owir the leff begynnyth þe tale
Whylom ther dwellid in Oxinford
A riche chorll that gystis had to bord
And of his craft he was a Carpenter
Wᵗith him þer was dwellyng a pore Skoler
That lernyd Art but al his fantecy
Was turnyd for to lern Astrology
And also he coude a certen of conclucions
For to demyn by interrogacions
Or yf that men axid him what shuld befal
Of euery thing I may nat rekyn al
This clerk was clepid hend Nicholas
Of dern love he coude and of solas
And ther to he was sly and ful pryve
And also like A maydyn meke for to se
And a chambir he had in that hostolory
Alone with outyn ony company
Ful fetously I dite with herbis sote
And he him selve as swete as the rote
Of Licoryse or of ony maner Cetewale
Sey what thowe wilt I shal it newir tel
To Child ne wyfe by him that harowid hel
Now Iohn quod Nicholas I wol nat ly
I have it found in myne Astrology
As I have lokid in the mone so bright
That now a monday next at quarter nyȝt
Shal fal a reyn and that so wild and wood
May Criste for bede it for his verry blode
This world he seid in les than in an oure
Shal al be dreynt so hydous is the shoure
Thus shal man kynde drench and lese her lyfe
This Carpenter answerd Alas my wyfe
And shal she drench alas my Alisoun
For sorow of this he fil al most adoun
And seid is ther no remedy in this case
Yis sir for God quod this end Nicholas
Yf thow wolt workyn aftir lore and rede
Thow maist nat workyn aftir thyn own hede
For this seith Salamon that was ful trewe
Work al by counsel and thow shalt newir rewe
And yf thow workyn wolt be good counseile
I vndir take with outyn mast or seile
Yit shal I save her and the and me
Hast thow nat herd howe sawid was Noye
When that our lord had warnyd him be forn
That al the world with watir shuld be lorn
Ȝis quod the Carpenter ful yore ago
Hast thow nat herd quod Nicholas also
The sorowe of Noye with his felship
Or that he myght gete his wyfe to ship
Him had be lewir I dare wele vndirtake
At þat tyme than al his wederis blake
That she had had a ship her selve alone
And therfor wotist thowe what is best to done
This axithe hast and of an hastyf thyng
Men may nat preche and make tarijng
A none go gete vs fast in to this Inne
A knedyng trowȝe or ellis a kemelyn
For eche of vs but loke loke that they be large
In wich wee mow swymyn in as in a barge
And have ther in vitaile sufficiaunte
But for O day and fy on the remnaunte
The watir shal a slake and go a way
A bout pryme oppon the next day
But Robyn may nat weet of this thy knave
Ne eke thy maydyn Gyl I may nat save
Axe nat why for thogh þou axe me
I wol nat tellyn Goddis pryvyte
Hit suffisith the but yf thy wit be mad
To have as grete a grace as noye had
Thy wyfe shal I wele save out of dout
Go now thy wey and spede the her about
Go nowe thy wey and spede the
And go fast ⁊and gete þese knedyng tubbis thre
Than shalt thowe hang hem in þe rofe ful hy
That no man shal our pryvite a spy
And eke an axe to smyte the with a to
When that the watyr comyth that we may go
And breke an hole an hygh oppon the gabil
In to the gardyn ward ouyr the stabil
That wee may frely pas forth our wey
When that the grete shour is passyn a wey
Than shul we swymmyn as merely I vndir take
As doith the white doke aftir the drake
Than wol I clepe how Alysoun howe Iohu
Be mery for the flode wel pas a none
And thow wolt sey heil mastir Nycholay
God morowe I se the wele for it is day
And than shal wee be lordis al our lyfe
Of al the world as was Noye and his wyfe
But of o thing I warn þe and þat ful right
Be wel awysid on that ilk nyght
When wee be entrid in to the ship bord
That noon of oos than speke no word
Ne clepe ne cry but be in his preyer
For it is Goddis hest leve and dere
